conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force on the entire wire frame considering both straight and curved parts.
The wire frame consists of a straight part (MN) and a semi-circular part. The straight part MN is perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The magnitude of the Ampere force on the straight part is given as F.
The length of the straight part is 2r (since it spans the diameter of the semi-circle).
The semi-circular part has a length of πr. The direction of the current in the semi-circular part is tangential to the circle at every point.
The magnetic field is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of the wire frame.
The force on a small segment dL of the semi-circular wire is given by dF = I dL × B.
Since the current I is constant and the magnetic field B is uniform, the total force on the semi-circular part can be found by integrating dF over the length of the semi-circle.
The direction of dF is radial at every point on the semi-circle, and these forces cancel out in pairs due to symmetry.
The net force on the semi-circular part is zero.
The total force is the sum of the forces on the straight part and the semi-circular part.
Since the force on the semi-circular part is zero, the total force is simply the force on the straight part.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is F.
